docs.lead_paragraph: ''One of the things I regret,'' the playwright said, ''is the passing of the experimental group theater.'' The speaker was Eugene O'Neill and the time was 1931. His obituary for innovation may have proven premature, but his concern persists, not least among those who attempt to bring new vision to the theater. A new season is opening in the regional, Off and Off Off Broadway theaters amid questions about whether the alternatives to Broadway can survive their own success. In the last 20 years, the numbers and influence of non-Broadway theaters have grown dramatically, as they have nurtured Pulitzer Prize-winning plays and playwrights and attracted prominent actors and actresses. At the very time of their artistic success, however, these theaters remain as financially vulnerable as ever, and they are contending with woes wrought by their own growth. Yesterday's basement theater is today's institution, large and unwieldy at times and held to heightened critical standards that are not always compatible with experimentation. ''It's not just a bunch of crazy kids south of 14th Street in unheated lofts,'' said Jane Moss, the executive director of ART New York, an association of 87 not-for-profit theaters. ''These theaters are collectively as important as the Metropolitan Opera.''

headline.main: AS OFF BROADWAY THRIVES, ITS PROBLEMS MOUNT
